revisions.rev:
{{distinguish|Indonesian Premier League}} {{Infobox football league | name = Indonesia Super League |image = ISL.jpg | country = {{IDN}} | confed = [[Asian Football Confederation|AFC]] ([[Asia]]) | founded = 2008 (before 2008, the top rank of professional
football competition in Indonesia
was the [[Liga Indonesia Premier Division|Premier Division]]) | teams = 18 | relegation = [[Liga Indonesia Premier Division|Premier Division]] | levels = 1 | domest_cup = [[Piala Indonesia]] | confed_cup = [[AFC Champions League]]
[[AFC Cup]] | most successful club = [[Persipura Jayapura]] (2) | champions = [[Persipura Jayapura]] | season = [[2010â11 Indonesia Super League|2010â11]] | sponsorship_name = Djarum Indonesia Super League | tv = [[antv]] | website = [http://www.ligaindonesia.co.id www.ligaindonesia.co.id] | current = [[2011â12 Indonesia Super League]] }} '''Indonesia Super League (ISL)''' ([[Indonesian language|Indonesian]]: ''Liga Super Indonesia'') is the highest level of [[Indonesian football league system|Liga Indonesia]]. ISL is a professional competition for [[football (soccer)|football]] clubs in [[Indonesia]]. This competition is managed by [[PT Liga Indonesia]], under supervision of the [[Football Association of Indonesia]] (PSSI). The 18 clubs participating in this top flight league need to pass a set of requirements and verification process, particularly related to professionalism and infrastructure feasibility. Prior to 2008, the top level of professional football competition in Indonesia was the [[Liga Indonesia Premier Division|Premier Division]] (in [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]]: ''Divisi Utama''), which is relegated to second tier afterwards. According to the ''AFC Final Assessment Ranking'' for 2009â2010 seasons (in which professional football leagues in Asia were ranked with respect to competitiveness, professionalism, marketability, and financial status of the league and its clubs - to determine the number of spots in the [[AFC Champions League]]), the Indonesia Super League was ranked 8th, the best in Southeast Asia.[http://www.the-afc.com/uploads/Documents/common/cms/afc/AFC%20PRO-LEAGUE%20AD-HOC%20COMMITTEE%20ASSESSMENT%20CHARTS%201.pdf Assessment and participation criteria for 2009â2010 seasons] 10,000 | 7th in [[2010-11 Liga Indonesia Premier Division|2010-11 Premier Division]] |- | [[PSMS Medan]] | [[Medan]] | [[North Sumatra]] | [[Teladan Stadium|Teladan]] | 15,000 | 8th in [[2010-11 Liga Indonesia Premier Division|2010-11 Premier Division]] |- | [[PSPS Pekanbaru]] | [[Kuantan Singingi Regency|Kuansing Regency]] | [[Riau]] | [[Sport Centre (Kuansing)|Sport Centre Kuansing]] | 25,000 | 11th in [[2010-11 Indonesia Super League|2010-11 Super League]] |- | [[Sriwijaya F.C.|Sriwijaya]] | [[Palembang]] | [[South Sumatera]] | [[Jakabaring Stadium|Jakabaring]] | 40,000 | 5th in [[2010-11 Indonesia Super League|2010-11 Super League]] |} == ISL U-21 == {{See also|Indonesia Super League U-21}} Building and managing a complete U-21 team is one of the requirements for clubs participating in the ISL. Those U-21 teams will participate in the [[Indonesia Super League U-21]] which is held in parallel with the main competition. In [[2009-10 Indonesia Super League|2009-10]], [[Persib Bandung U-21]] team won the league. Prior to 2008, the highest level of junior level competitions in Indonesia was U-23 League Cup. == Championship history == {{See also|List of Indonesian football champions}} {| class="toccolours" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse: collapse; text-align: left; width: 50%;" |- style="background:#efefef; text-align: center" !Year !Champions !Runners-up |- style="" |[[2008-09 Indonesia Super League|2008-09]] |[[Persipura Jayapura]] |[[Persiwa Wamena]] |- |[[2009-10 Indonesia Super League|2009-10]] | [[Arema Indonesia]] | [[Persipura Jayapura]] |- |[[2010-11 Indonesia Super League|2010-11]] | [[Persipura Jayapura]] | [[Arema Indonesia]] |} Before 2008, the highest level of professional football competition in Indonesia was the [[Liga Indonesia Premier Division|Premier Division]]. It used the combination format of ''double round-robin'' first round and ''single eliminations'' second round. Indonesia Super League uses the ''double round-robin'' competition format. Considering only these two ISL editions, [[Persipura Jayapura]] is considered as the best achieving clubs, since they could finish the first and second position consecutively. Considering the whole history of top level of professional football league in Indonesia, [[Persebaya Surabaya]], [[Persik Kediri]] along with [[Persipura Jayapura]] are the best achievers, winning the competitions twice. === ISL U-21 champions === {| class="toccolours" border="1" cellpadding="2" style="border-collapse: collapse; text-align: left; width: 50%;" |- style="background:#efefef; text-align: center" !Year !Champions !Runners-up |- style="" |[[2008â09 Indonesia Super League U-21|2008-09]] |[[Pelita Jaya U-21]] |[[Persita U-21]] |- |[[2009-10 Indonesia Super League U-21|2009-10]] | [[Persib Bandung U-21]] | [[Pelita Jaya U-21]] |- |[[2011 Indonesia Super League U-21|2011]] | [[Persela U-21]] | [[Semen Padang FC U-21]] |} == Season 2009â10 clubs == The following clubs are participating in the [[2009â10 Indonesia Super League|2009â10]] season. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Club{{br}} !Position{{br}}in [[2008-09 Indonesia Super League|2008]] !First season in

Year ! Club |- | [[2008-09 Indonesia Super League|2008-09]] | â |- | [[2009-10 Indonesia Super League|2009-10]] | [[Arema FC|Arema Indonesia]] |- | [[2010-11 Indonesia Super League|2010-11]] | â |} ==Sponsorship== *2008-2011: [[Djarum]] (Djarum Indonesia Super League) ==Foreign players== The first edition of ISL used the same format for foreign players as the previous edition of top layer league in Indonesia, which allows club to have 5 foreign players from any countries without further restrictions. Only 3 of them are allowed to play together in a match. However, since the 2009-10 edition, [[PSSI|Indonesian FA]] has applied a new restriction as known as "3+2" format, in which at least 2 of 5 foreign players in every club are originated from Asian countries. Furthermore, those foreign players need to conform with the following condition:[http://www.supersoccer.co.id/liga-indonesia/ulasan/content/read/catatan-disl-20092010/ Catatan DISL 2009/2010] * Players from European or American countries should have played in the second division (third layer of their respective competition system). * Players from African countries should have played in (at least) in the first division (second layer of their respective competition system). * Players from Asian countries should have played (at least) in the premier/super league (highest layer of their respective competition system). * Players from Southeast Asian countries should be in their national team. In 2010-2011 edition, [[PSSI|Indonesian FA]] introduced a new restriction regarding registration of new foreign players from African countries. Players from African countries who have never played before in Indonesia Super League shall be an international player for his country. The respective players have to show formal evidences that they have played for their country in official [[FIFA]] matches. Players failed to show such evidences will not get permit to play in Indonesia Super League 2010-2011.[http://www.waspada.co.id/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=138226:aturan-baru-pemain-afrika-di-lsi&catid=22:nasional&Itemid=41] === [[2011â12 Indonesia Super League|2011â12]] foreign players === {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! width="190" | Club ! width="170" | Visa 1 ! width="170" | Visa 2 ! width="170" | Visa 3 ! width="170" | Visa 4 ! width="170" | Visa 5 ! width="170" | Non-Visa Foreign |- style="vertical-align:top;" | '''[[Arema FC]]''' | {{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Noh Alam Shah]] | {{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Muhammad Ridhuan]] | {{flagicon|Uruguay}} [[Esteban Guillen]] | {{flagicon|Slovakia}} [[Roman Chmelo]] | ''None'' | ''None'' |- style="vertical-align:top;" | '''[[Deltras Sidoarjo]]''' | {{flagicon|South Korea}} [[Shin Hyun Joon (footballer)|Shin Hyun-Joon]] | {{flagicon|Croatia}} [[Mijo Dadic]] | {{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Walter Bruzuela]] | {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Sean Rooney (footballer)|Sean Rooney]] | ''None'' | ''None'' |- style="vertical-align:top;" | '''[[Mitra Kukar FC]]''' | {{flagicon|Cameroon}} [[Pierre Njanka]] | {{flagicon|Serbia}} [[Nemanja ObriÄ]] | {{flagicon|South Korea}} [[Lee Sang-Min]] | {{flagicon|England}} [[Marcus Bent]] | ''None'' | ''None'' |- style="vertical-align:top;" | '''[[Pelita Jaya]]''' | {{flagicon|Serbia}} [[SaÅ¡a RadivojeviÄ]] | {{flagicon|Macedonia}} [[Aleksandar Bajevski]] | {{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Mohd Safee Mohd Sali|Safee Sali]] | {{flagicon|Bulgaria}} [[Stanislav Zhekov]] | ''None'' | {{flagicon|Netherlands}} [[Diego Michiels]]1 2[http://www.bolaindo.com/?page=berita&sub=detail&id=17052 Paspor Tiga Pemain Naturaliasi Tuntas]

[[Thierry Gathuessi]] | {{flagicon|Brazil}} [[Hilton Moreira]] | {{flagicon|South Korea}} [[Lim Joon-Sik]] | ''None'' | ''None'' |} These players do not fill a Visa position:
1Those players who were [[born]] and started their professional career abroad but have since gained [[Indonesia|Indonesia Residency]];
2[[Alien (law)|Foreign residents]] or [[Overseas Indonesian|foreign residents of Indonesian descent]] who have chosen to represent [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesian national team]];
